facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1006 of 1964 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal No. 1006 of- 1964. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 7, 1963 of the Patna High Court in Misc. Judl. Case No.343 of 1961.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated August 7, 1963 of Patna High Court in Misc. Judl. Case No.343 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 7, 1963 of the Patna High Court in Misc. Judl. Case No.343 of 1961. Niren De, Additional Solicitor-General, A. N. Sinha and D. Gupta, for the appellants.

facts.text: Appellant carries on business in petroleum products in Patna district.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is carrying on business in petroleum products in the Patna district. Habibur Rahman was serving as a watchman and Abdul Rahim as a driver in the permanent employ of the appellant at the Dinapore depot.

facts.text: Habibur Rahman served as watchman in permanent employ of appellant at Dinapore depot.

anchor.surface_text: Habibur Rahman was serving as a watchman and Abdul Rahim as a driver in the permanent employ of the appellant at the Dinapore depot. They were charged with gross misconduct and an enquiry was held ,by the appellant in that companynection.

facts.text: Abdul Rahim served as driver in permanent employ of appellant at Dinapore depot.

anchor.surface_text: and Abdul Rahim as a driver in the permanent employ of the appellant at the Dinapore depot. They were charged with gross misconduct and an enquiry was held ,by the appellant in that companynection. Habibur Rahman was dis- ,charged on May 5, 1960 and one months pay in lieu of numberice was ,offered to him.

facts.text: Habibur Rahman and Abdul Rahim charged with gross misconduct and enquiry held by appellant.

anchor.surface_text: They were charged with gross misconduct and an enquiry was held ,by the appellant in that companynection. Habibur Rahman was dis- ,charged on May 5, 1960 and one months pay in lieu of numberice was ,offered to him. Abdul Rahim was dismissed on April 22, 1960.

facts.text: Habibur Rahman discharged on May 5, 1960 and one month's pay in lieu of notice offered.

anchor.surface_text: Habibur Rahman was dis- ,charged on May 5, 1960 and one months pay in lieu of numberice was ,offered to him. Abdul Rahim was dismissed on April 22, 1960. These two employees made applications under s. 26 of the Act in December 1960 before the labour companyrt.

facts.text: Abdul Rahim dismissed on April 22, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Abdul Rahim was dismissed on April 22, 1960. These two employees made applications under s. 26 of the Act in December 1960 before the labour companyrt. These applications were -obviously barred by time.

facts.text: Habibur Rahman and Abdul Rahim made applications under s.26 in December 1960 before labour court.

anchor.surface_text: These two employees made applications under s. 26 of the Act in December 1960 before the labour companyrt. These applications were -obviously barred by time. The labour companyrt companydoned the delay without giving any numberice to the appellant on the question and issued numberice to show cause why the dismissal discharge be number set aside.

facts.text: Applications under s.26 were barred by time.

anchor.surface_text: These applications were -obviously barred by time. The labour companyrt companydoned the delay without giving any numberice to the appellant on the question and issued numberice to show cause why the dismissal discharge be number set aside.

facts.text: Labour court condoned delay without notice to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The labour companyrt companydoned the delay without giving any numberice to the appellant on the question and issued numberice to show cause why the dismissal discharge be number set aside. On receipt of this numberice, the appellant learnt that delay in making the applications had been companydoned without hearing it.

facts.text: Labour court issued notice to appellant to show cause why dismissal/discharge should not be set aside.

anchor.surface_text: and issued numberice to show cause why the dismissal discharge be number set aside. On receipt of this numberice, the appellant learnt that delay in making the applications had been companydoned without hearing it. Consequently the appellant moved the High Court at Patna under Art. 226 of the Constitution for quashing the order of the labour companyrt companydoning the delay on the ground that it had been passed without hearing the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant moved Patna High Court under Art.226 for quashing labour court's condonation order.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently the appellant moved the High Court at Patna under Art. 226 of the Constitution for quashing the order of the labour companyrt companydoning the delay on the ground that it had been passed without hearing the appellant. Thereafter in March 1961 the appellant moved the labour companyrt for recalling the ex parts order of companydonation.

facts.text: Appellant moved labour court in March 1961 for recalling ex parte condonation order.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter in March 1961 the appellant moved the labour companyrt for recalling the ex parts order of companydonation. The labour companyrt heard the appellant on March 27, 1961 and decided on April 4, 1961 to companydone the delay and -confirm the ex parte order already passed.

facts.text: Labour court heard appellant on March 27, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: The labour companyrt heard the appellant on March 27, 1961 and decided on April 4, 1961 to companydone the delay and -confirm the ex parte order already passed. Thereupon the appellant filed another writ petition in the High Court out of which the present appeal has arisen.

facts.text: Labour court on April 4, 1961 condoned delay and confirmed ex parte order after hearing appellant.

anchor.surface_text: and decided on April 4, 1961 to companydone the delay and -confirm the ex parte order already passed. Thereupon the appellant filed another writ petition in the High Court out of which the present appeal has arisen. In this petition the order dated April 4, 1961 was attacked on various grounds.

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition in Patna High Court attacking April 4, 1961 order and validity of s.26.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the appellant filed another writ petition in the High Court out of which the present appeal has arisen. In this petition the order dated April 4, 1961 was attacked on various grounds. Besides the appellant also attacked the validity of s. 26 of the Act.

facts.text: Several petitions attacking validity of s.26 heard together by Patna High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Besides the appellant also attacked the validity of s. 26 of the Act. It may be mentioned that a number of other petitions had also been filed before the High Court attacking the validity of s. 26 of the Act. All these petitions were heard together and the High Court held that ,S. 26 was companystitutionally valid.

facts.text: Patna High Court held s.26 constitutionally valid.

anchor.surface_text: All these petitions were heard together and the High Court held that ,S. 26 was companystitutionally valid. It also held that the order of April 4, 1961 showed that delay had been companydoned after hearing the .appellant and therefore there was numbercause for interference with that order.

facts.text: Patna High Court held no cause for interference with April 4, 1961 order as delay condoned after hearing appellant.

anchor.surface_text: It also held that the order of April 4, 1961 showed that delay had been companydoned after hearing the .appellant and therefore there was numbercause for interference with that order. The appellant moved the High Court for a certificate to appeal to this Court, which was refused.

facts.text: Appellant applied for certificate to appeal to Supreme Court, refused by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant moved the High Court for a certificate to appeal to this Court, which was refused. It then applied for special leave, which was granted and that is how the matter has .come before us.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave.

anchor.surface_text: It then applied for special leave, which was granted and that is how the matter has .come before us. The attack of the appellant is on the proviso to s. 26  1  of ,,the Act, and the only ground that has been urged before us on its ,behalf is that that proviso suffers from the vice of excessive delega- tion and should therefore be struck down.

facts.text: State Government framed r.20(1) specifying 11 acts of misconduct.

anchor.surface_text: By virtue of that power, the State Government framed r. 20  1  which specifies as many as II acts which are to be treated as misconduct on proof of which numbernotice as required by s. 26  1  would be necessary.

facts.text: Supreme Court held proviso to s.26 not ultra vires due to excessive delegation.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances we are of opinion that the proviso to S. 26  1  is number ultra vires because of the vice of excessive delegation.

facts.text: Supreme Court did not allow argument on labour court's condonation order being bad.

anchor.surface_text: Learned companynsel for the appellant also wanted to urge that the order of the labour companyrt companydoning delay was bad. We have number allowed him to pursue this point.

facts.text: Appeal dismissed with costs to respondent No.4.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal therefore fails and is hereby dismissed with companyts to respondent No.

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 26, Bihar Shops and Establishments Act, 1954
concepts.unlisted_description: Notice of dismissal or discharge; applications to labour court for challenging dismissal/discharge

anchor.surface_text: The relevant part of s. 26 is in these terms Notice of dismissal or discharge- I  No employer shall dismiss or discharge from his employment any employee who has been in such employment continuously for a period of not less than six months except for a. reasonable cause and without giving such employee at least one months notice or one months wages in lieu. of such notice Provided that such notice shall not be necessary where the services of such employee are dispensed with on a charge of such misconduct as may be prescribed by the State Government, supported by satisfactory evidence recorded at an inquiry held for the purpose. It is not necessary to set out the rest of s. 26 for that is not under, attack.

concepts.interpretation: Requires one month's notice or pay in lieu for dismissal/discharge of employee with 6+ months service, except for prescribed misconduct proved at inquiry

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: d been companydoned after hearing the .appellant and therefore there was numbercause for interference with that order. The appellant moved the High Co

anchor.surface_text: Looking at the list of several items of misconduct which have been prescribed by the State Government under. r. 20 1 , we are of the opinion that the State Government also properly understood the guidance which was contained in the words of s. 26 1  and its proviso and has prescribed a list of what are clearly major misconducts for the purpose and has also included therein by the last clause breach of the provisions of the Standing Orders applicable to the establishment and certified under the Industrial Employment  Standing Orders  Act, 1946.

concepts.interpretation: Words provide sufficient guidance for specifying major misconducts justifying dismissal without notice

anchor.surface_text: the only ground that has been urged before us on its ,behalf is that that proviso suffers from the vice of excessive delega- tion and should therefore be struck down. The relevant part of s. 26 is in these terms Notice of dismissal or discharge- I  No employer shall dismiss or discharge from his employment any employee who has been in such employment continuously for a period of not less than six months except for a. reasonable cause and without giving such employee at least one months notice or one months wages in lieu.

concepts.unlisted_description: Unconstitutional delegation of legislative power without sufficient guidance

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that there is no substance in this conten- tion. Under s. 40 of the Act, the State Government has been given the power to make rules to carry out the purposes of the Act. Clause  c  of s. 40  2  specifically empowers the State Government to frame rules to provide for the nature of misconduct of an employee for which his services may be dispensed with without notice. By virtue of that power, the State Government framed r. 20 1  which specifies as many as II acts which are to be treated as misconduct on proof of which notice as required by s. 26  1  would be necessary.

concepts.interpretation: No excessive delegation as s.26 provides guidance by context of major misconducts in industrial law justifying dismissal; legislature intended flexibility via rules

issues.text: the constitutionality of s. 26 of the Bihar Shops and Establishments Act

anchor.surface_text: The main question raised in this appeal by special leave against the judgment of the Patna High Court is .the companystitutionality of s. 26 of the Bihar Shops and Establishments Act, No. 8 of 1954,  hereinafter referred to as the Act . The question arises in this way.
